questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute pyelonephritis?

choices.text: CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice
Commonly associated with uric acid stones
Renal scarring is common in untreated cases
The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Patients with acute pyelonephritis are more likely to have struvite stones, not uric acid stones. This is because of infection with urea-splitting organisms such as proteus that release ammonia. This makes the urine alkaline and promotes the formation of struvite stones.

Acute pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidneys. Ascending infection in the urinary tract is the most common route. It is more common in young, sexually active women. Up to 50% of children with urinary infections have an underlying anatomical abnormality (e.g., reflux or obstruction). 

Clinical features include:

  • Prodromal symptoms such as headache, lassitude, vomiting
  • Flank pain, fever, rigor
  • Pyuria and occasionally hematuria

CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice to rule out pyonephrosis. 

The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent renal scarring. Surgery is indicated only if antibiotic therapy fails.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with pyrexia and left flank pain. On examination, Murphy's punch sign is positive. CECT abdomen done is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history with Murphy's punch sign positive, and streaks of gas on CECT abdomen point to a diagnosis of emphysematous pyelonephritis. Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is associated with an acute necrotizing infection of the kidney by gas-producing organisms that occurs predominantly in diabetic patients. E. coli produces carbon dioxide by the fermentation of sugar.

Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. It can be associated with tenderness at the costovertebral angle known as Murphy's punch sign.

CECT abdomen shows an enlarged destructed renal parenchyma with small linear streaks of gas.

Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with drainage. In patients who fail to respond to treatment, nephrectomy is considered.

Note: Clostridium species are the most common causative organisms in emphysematous cholecystitis.

Murphy's punch sign is also seen in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney. The below image shows the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column.

questions.text: A woman is referred to you for evaluation of recurrent episodes of right flank pain and high-grade fever. She also had a history of recurrent urinary calculi in the past. CECT abdomen done is shown below. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with CECT abdomen showing bear paw sign is suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Subcapsular nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with XGP.

It is a form of chronic pyelonephritis seen most frequently in middle-aged diabetic women and, rarely, in children. XGP is most commonly caused by proteus followed by E. coli. The disease is usually unilateral and is associated with prolonged obstructing nephrolithiasis.

CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyxes showing a multiloculated appearance. This is referred to as the bear paw sign. Histology shows foamy, lipid-laden macrophages.

questions.text: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal tuberculosis. 

Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB. 

Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. 

ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys.

Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma and tubules.

questions.text:
A man presented to the OPD with hematuria and intermittent right flank pain. He received ATT for pulmonary TB two years ago. Urine analysis revealed pus cells, and no growth was seen on culture. Which of the following lesions are associated with this condition?
  1. Papillary ulcer
  2. Pyonephrosis
  3. Ghost calyces
  4. Perinephric abscess
  5. Pseudocalculi
questions.solution:
The given history of pulmonary TB and presence of sterile pyuria on urine culture is suggestive of a diagnosis of renal tuberculosis. All of the above lesions can be seen in renal TB. 

Lesions in the kidney include:

  • Papillary ulcer - earliest lesion
  • Pyonephrosis/ Putty kidney - caused by multiple scattered papillary ulcers undergoing caseous necrosis, which later become filled with pus
  • Cement kidney -  caused by calcifications in putty kidney
  • Perinephric abscess -  by extension of pyonephrosis or tuberculous renal abscess
  • Pseudocalculi - occurs when calcium gets deposited in a papillary ulcer healed with fibrosis
  • Ghost calyces - caused by the destruction of the calyces
  • Thimble bladder - caused by fibrosis. The earliest sign is the paleness of bladder mucosa. managed by ileocystoplasty
  • Golf hole ureteric orifice - Dilated ureteric orifice. Managed by ureter reimplantation.

questions.text: The Bosniak classification system is used in assessing patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The Bosniak classification system is used for assessing patients with renal cysts.

It divides renal cystic masses into five classes based on imaging characteristics seen on CECT. It is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of clinical follow-up or treatment.

Renal cyst class Risk of malignancy Workup
1 0% Nil
2 0% Nil
2F 5% USG/ CT follow up
3 50%
  • Partial nephrectomy
  • Radiofrequency ablation - in elderly or poor surgical candidates
4 100% Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text: An ultrasound abdomen done for evaluation of flank pain in a man revealed a large mass arising from the right kidney. CECT abdomen done showed the presence of a central stellate scar. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presence of a central stellate scar on CECT is suggestive of a diagnosis of oncocytoma.

Oncocytoma is the most common benign renal tumor. It arises from cells rich in mitochondria. Familial type is associated with Birt Hogg Dube syndrome. Most patients remain asymptomatic even with large oncocytomas. In some cases, it may present as an abdominal lump.

The cystic variant of the tumor is classified as Bosniak class III on CECT. On histological examination, large eosinophilic cells owing to an abundance of mitochondria are seen arranged in distinct nests. Partial nephrectomy is the preferred treatment. 

Note: Central stellate scar on CECT is also seen in chromophobe RCC and focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver.

The given CECT shows an enhancing right renal mass with a central stellate scar

The given slide shows large eosinophilic cells arranged in nests

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with severe back pain and vomiting. He was diagnosed to have tuberous sclerosis during childhood. CT scan revealed the presence of renal tumors with high-fat content as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and CT findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of angiomyolipoma. 

Angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign neoplasm of the kidney. It contains blood vessels, smooth muscles, and fat, and arises from perivascular epithelioid cells. It can occur in isolated forms or may be associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Patients can either be asymptomatic or may present with abdominal pain or a lump. Some patients may also present with massive hemorrhage referred to as Wunderlich’s syndrome. Lenk’s triad seen in patients with Wunderlich’s syndrome includes:

  • Abdominal mass
  • Abdominal pain
  • Shock

Due to the presence of abundant fat tissue, they can be easily identified on CT scans. Immunohistochemistry is positive for HMB 45. Treatment includes:

  • Asymptomatic tumors and tumors less than 4 cm in size - Observation with serial CECT
  • Symptomatic tumors and tumors more than 4 cm in size - Partial nephrectomy/ nephron-sparing surgery 
  • Bleeding tumors - Angioembolization followed by partial nephrectomy

Everolimus is FDA approved for the treatment of AMLs.

Note: HMB45 is positive on IHC for malignant melanoma and angiomyolipomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Grawitz tumor?

choices.text: Derived from the proximal tubular epithelium
Clear cell is the most common histological type

questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) also known as Grawitz tumor or hypernephroma, is a radio-resistant tumor.

RCC accounts for 85% of renal neoplasms in adults. It is more common in males between the sixth to seventh decades. Clear-cell RCC is the most common type of renal cell cancer.

The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron is usually the site of origin of RCC.

Risk factors for RCC:

  • Smoking
  • Obesity
  • Family history of RCC
  • Drugs like phenacetin and diuretics
  • Thorotrast exposure
  • Increased protein intake

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the presentation of renal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Flank pain is the most common presentation
It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
It may be associated with pulsatile bony metastasis
Palpable abdominal mass is part of the classic triad seen in RCC

questions.solution:
The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria.

The classic triad (seen in <10% of cases) includes :

  • Gross hematuria 
  • Flank pain 
  • Palpable abdominal mass 

Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC.

Patients may also present with paraneoplastic syndromes. RCC can give rise to pulsatile bony metastases.

questions.text: A man presents with intermittent hematuria and flank pain for 2 months. He is a known smoker and is found to be anemic. Further investigations reveal an enhancing lesion arising from the right kidney. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is not likely to be seen in his condition?
questions.solution:
Hematuria and flank pain in a known smoker with the given investigation findings is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma. Cerebellar degeneration is not a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC include:

Endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes -

  • Stauffer syndrome - non-metastatic liver dysfunction, characterized by elevated serum bilirubin, ALP, and prolonged prothrombin time
  • Hypercalcemia - due to increased vitamin D, PTH-related protein
  • Hypertension
  • Polycythemia
  • Galactorrhea
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Alterations in glucose metabolism

Non-endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes include Lambert Eaton syndrome (neuromyopathy), amyloidosis, anemia, vasculopathy, nephropathy, coagulopathy, elevated ESR, prostaglandin elevation.

Elevated ESR is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC.

Note: Cerebellar degeneration is a paraneoplastic syndrome in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

Clinical Syndromes/ 

Endocrinopathies

Major Forms of Underlying Cancer

Causal Mechanism

Cushing Syndrome

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Pancreatic carcinoma

Neural tumours

Renal carcinoma

ACTH or ACTH- like substance

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Intracranial neoplasms

Antidiuretic hormone or atrial natriuretic hormones

Hypercalcemia

Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

Breast carcinoma

Renal carcinoma

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma

Parathyroid hormone-related protein(PTHRP), TGF-a, TNF, IL-1

Hypoglycaemia

Ovarian carcinoma

Fibrosarcoma

Other mesenchymal sarcomas

Insulin or insulin-like substance

Polycythemia

Renal carcinoma

Cerebellar haemangioma

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Erythropoietin

Osteomalacia

Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor

FGF-23

Disseminated intrvascular coagulation

Acute promyelocytic leukemia

Prostatic carcinoma

Tumor products activate clotting

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text:
Lab values from a routine workup done for a hypertensive man are given below. Further investigations revealed hepatosplenomegaly with a 5.5 cm tumor arising from the right kidney. No signs of metastasis were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Total bilirubin = 3.1 mg/dl

ALP = 230 U/L

Albumin = 2.8mg/dl

Prothrombin time = 16.2 sec

Hypergammaglobulinemia
questions.solution:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of Stauffer syndrome in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. 

Stauffer syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. It is a non-metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6. It is characterized by the presence of hepatosplenomegaly with no features of metastasis and the following lab findings:

  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Raised ALP
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time

Option A: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to the development of renal failure in patients with advanced chronic liver disease.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction (HVOTO).

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma is characterized by multiple losses of entire chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Chromophobe type renal cell carcinomas (RCC) are uniquely associated with multiple losses of entire chromosomes, including chromosomes 1, 2, 6, 10, 13, 17, and 21. Thus, they show extreme hypodiploidy.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A man was referred for the evaluation of an unsteady gait with weakness of his legs for the past 1 month. He gave a history of similar problems in his brother. Imaging revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas and bilateral renal masses suggestive of RCC.  Which histological type of this renal malignancy is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma which along with the family history points to a diagnosis of von Hippel Lindau’s disease (VHL). Clear cell RCC is the most common type associated with VHL disease. 

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is caused by a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A second hit can increase the predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina, and clear cell renal carcinoma(in 40-60%).

The given slide shows clear cell RCC. 

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

Syndrome Mutation in 
Clinical manifestations
von Hippel–Lindau VHL gene (3p 25-26)
  • Clear cell RCC, renal cysts
  • Retinal angiomas (benign)
  • CNS hemangioblastomas (benign)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Cystadenoma
  • Endolymphatic sac tumors
Hereditary papillary RCC C-met proto-oncogene (7q31)
  • Multiple & bilateral type1 papillary RCC
Tuberous sclerosis  TSC1 (9q34) TSC2 (16p13)
  • Clear cell RCC
  • Multiple renal angiomyolipomas
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Cutaneous angiofibroma
  • Periungual fibroma
  • Shagreen patch
  • Ashleaf macules
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma
  • Subependymal nodules
  • Cortical tubers in CNS
  • Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis
Birt–Hogg–Dube  BHD gene: Folliculin (17p11)
  • Multiple chromophobe RCC
  • Hybrid oncocytic tumor 
  • Oncocytomas                   
  • Clear-cell RCC          
  • Papillary RCC                 
  • Facial fibrofoliculomas   
  • Lung cysts               
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
Hereditary leiomyomatosis Fumarate hydratase (1q42-43)
  • Type 2 papillary RCC   
  • Collecting-duct RCC 
  • Leiomyomas of skin or uterus
  • Uterine leiomyosarcomas
Cowden syndrome PTEN (10q23) 
  • Benign and malignant breast tumors 
  • Epithelial thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary RCC or other histological subtypes
 

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

BHD: Birt Hogg Dube

TSC: Tuberous sclerosis complex

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method of diagnostic investigation in patients suspected to have hypernephroma?
questions.solution:
The most common method of diagnostic investigation in hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Characteristic features of RCC on CT scan include:

  • Enhancement of the lesion after injection of IV contrast
  • Thickened irregular walls
  • Thickened or enhanced septa within the mass or multilocular mass

CT scan has replaced IVP and ultrasound as the radiological modality of choice to evaluate renal masses.

MRI can be performed for diagnosing poorly characterized renal masses on CT or if a CT scan is contraindicated (in case of allergy to IV contrast). It also helps in defining tumor extension into the renal vein or IVC. 

The below image shows a cystic tumor involving the left kidney suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in patients with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries.

The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain.

Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes.

The image below shows multiple round opacities in bilateral lungs suggestive of cannonball metastasis in the lungs.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: In patients with which of the following findings on CECT abdomen, would you stage the tumor as T3 stage of RCC?

choices.text: 8.5 cm tumor limited to the kidney
5 cm tumor limited to the kidney
12 cm tumor involving the supra-diaphragmatic IVC
11.5 cm tumor extending into the ipsilateral adrenal gland

questions.solution:
In the T3c stage of hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma, the tumor spreads to the supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC.

TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma

T: Primary tumor 
T1: Limited to the kidney, <7 cm
T2: Limited to the kidney, >7 cm

T3: Tumor extension into major veins or perinephric tissues, but not into ipsilateral adrenal gland or beyond Gerota's fascia

  • T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond the Gerota's fascia
  • T3b: Spread to infra-diaphragmatic IVC
  • T3c: Spread to supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC
T4: Involves ipsilateral adrenal gland or invades beyond Gerota's fascia
N: Regional lymph nodes
N0: No nodal involvement
N1: Metastatic involvement of regional lymph node(s)
M: Metastasis
M0: No distant metastases
M1: Distant metastases

Note: Robson staging is a less commonly used staging system for RCC. Fuhrmann grading is used for grading RCC.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is the treatment of choice for tumors <4 cm.

Indications for partial nephrectomy:

  • Tumors < 4cm
  • Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm
  • Bilateral tumors
  • Tumor in solitary kidneys
  • Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction.

Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. 

Treatment of renal cell carcinoma: 

RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Staging  Description  Management 
Stage 1  Tumor <7 cm, confined to the kidney Partial nephrectomy 
Stage 2  Tumor >7 cm, confined to the kidney Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 3  Tumor extends into the major veins or adrenal gland with intact Gerota’s fascia or regional lymph nodes involved.  Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 4  Tumor invades beyond Gerota fascia (including contiguous extension into the ipsilateral adrenal gland) 
  • Debulking surgery
  • mTOR inhibitors such as everolimus, sirolimus
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors: sunitinib, sorafenib

Radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is no longer removed except in cases of obvious tumor involvement. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumors and enlarged lymph nodes.

Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/metastatic tumors. 

Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

questions.text: You are assisting in a radical nephrectomy in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Early ligation of vessels is performed to reduce tumor spread
It includes removal of the kidney with Gerota's fascia
Excision of ipsilateral adrenal gland is done in all the cases
Regional lymphadenectomy is done for tumors more than 10 cm in size

questions.solution:
Excision of the ipsilateral adrenal gland in radical nephrectomy is done only if the tumor is adherent to it.

Classical radical nephrectomy includes:

  • Early ligation of the renal artery and vein to prevent tumor spread
  • Removal of the kidney with primary dissection external to the Gerota's fascia
  • A complete regional lymphadenectomy from the crus of the diaphragm to the aortic bifurcation

Regional lymphadenectomy is not required in every radical nephrectomy. It is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Enlarged lymph nodes on imaging
  • Cytoreductive surgery for metastatic disease
  • Tumor size > 10 cm
  • Nuclear grade ≥ 3
  • Sarcomatoid histology in renal tumor
  • Presence of tumor necrosis on imaging
  • Extrarenal tumor extension
  • Tumor thrombus
  • Direct tumoral invasion of adjacent organs

questions.text: Which is the most common abdominal tumor seen in children?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal tumor of childhood.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood.

The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on CT, but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma.

Features Wilms tumor (Nephroblastoma) Neuroblastoma
Age group Peaks at 3-4 years of age Age <2 years of age
Presentation Painless abdominal mass Painful abdominal mass
Associated syndromes

WAGR syndrome

Beckwith Weidman syndrome

Denys Drash syndrome

 Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome
Calcifications Uncommon (10-15%) Very common (90%)
Margins Well circumscribed Poorly marginated
Vascular invasion Extends into the IVC and renal vein Encases vascular structures but does not invade them
Metastasis Lung (most common) Bone (most common)
Findings on CECT Peripheral calcifications Intratumoral calcifications with vascular encasement

questions.text: A boy was brought by his parents, with complaints of blood in his urine. A left-sided reniform mass was palpated. Further investigations were suggestive of Wilms tumor. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most cases occur in children between 2-5 years of age
It is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood
Early metastasis occurs to the liver
Nephrogenic rest cells are precursor lesions

questions.solution:
Metastasis to the lungs occurs early in Wilms tumor. Liver, bone, and brain metastasis is rare.

Wilms tumor or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. It is commonly seen in children between 2-5 years of age. More than one-third of the cases contain precursor lesions known as nephrogenic rests. 

Asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally is the most common presentation. Patients may also present with:

  • Abdominal pain
  • Gross painless hematuria
  • Fever
  • Hypertension

Most unilateral tumors are treated by chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and dactinomycin) followed by nephrectomy. 

Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done. Partial nephrectomy is considered if all the following conditions are met:

  • The tumor involves only one pole of the kidney
  • No evidence of collecting system or vascular involvement
  • The involved kidney has an appreciable function
  • There are clear margins between tumor and surrounding structures

It is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney. Preoperative chemotherapy can be used in these cases to induce tumor shrinkage.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text:
A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had a history of hematuria two weeks back which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a right-sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What all investigations will you do?
  1. CECT abdomen
  2. PET-CT
  3. 24-hour urinary VMA
  4. FNAC
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a ballotable renal mass with hematuria in a 3-year-old child are suggestive of Wilms tumor and FNAC is not done in this condition.

Investigations in suspected cases of Wilms tumor:

  • Laboratory study - shows hematuria, polycythemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated APTT
  • USG with doppler study of renal veins - for evaluation of the collecting system and to look for tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava
  • CECT abdomen - to identify the extent of the disease, to access the contralateral kidney, and for metastasis
  • MRI - not used routinely as it requires sedation
  • Positron emission tomography(PET) scan - to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions

Diagnosis should be made by imaging studies and it is confirmed after nephrectomy. A biopsy is discouraged in this condition as it results in disease upstaging. Only in cases with atypical presentation such as older age, signs of infection, etc, or with unusual imaging findings a core needle biopsy via the posterior approach can be performed. 

Note: Neuroblastoma also presents similar to Wilms tumor. It is commonly seen in children of preschool age. Affected children commonly present with a palpable abdominal mass and the most common site of the tumor is the retroperitoneum. Therefore, this disease becomes an important differential diagnosis. So we should also test for the presence of vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) in this patient to exclude this tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor in determining the prognosis of a child with Wilms tumor?

choices.text: Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.solution:
The most important prognostic factor in Wilms tumor is the histology of the tumor.

Wilms tumor (WT) is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the metanephric blastema, with no differentiation into tubules or glomeruli. It usually arises from three tissue elements (triphasic tumor):

  1. Blastema (poor prognosis if the blastemal component is more)
  2. Epithelium 
  3. Stroma

Wilms tumors lacking anaplasia (presence of atypical, polyploid mitotic figures, large nuclear size, and hyperchromasia) are designated as having “favorable histology".

questions.text: Which of the following staging systems is used for staging of Wilms tumor in a child posted for partial nephrectomy post neoadjuvant chemotherapy?

choices.text: International society of paediatric oncology staging
American joint committee on cancer staging

questions.solution:
International society of pediatric oncology (SIOP) is the post-chemotherapy staging system used for Wilms tumor. The SIOP approach involves the shrinkage of the tumor using preoperative chemotherapy. 

Option A: Children's oncology group (COG) staging is used for post-operative staging followed by chemotherapy. It was previously known as national Wilms tumor staging (NWTSG).

Option C: TNM staging (AJCC) is used for staging internal malignancies such as gastric, renal, breast, etc.

Option D: Shimada staging is used for neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A child with a left-sided renal mass is suspected to have Wilms tumor. CECT also revealed a small mass on the right kidney. A frozen section done intraoperatively confirmed the presence of bilateral Wilms tumor. What is the stage of the tumor in this child?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with bilateral involvement of kidneys is stage V.

Children's oncology group (COG) staging system

Stage I Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.
Stage II Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.
Stage III Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor.
Stage IV Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.) or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region.
Stage V Metastasis to opposite kidney (bilateral renal involvement).
